hints_html: What’s the only differential equation you know from this course?
hints_latex: What's the only differential equation you know from this course?
hints_raw: What's the only differential equation you know from this course?
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
This one you just have to know by heart for the exam.

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dT}{dt} = k(T-T_{s}) = k(T-19)\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

When an apple is taken from a refrigerator, its temperature is \(3^{\circ}C\). After 30 minutes in a \(19^{\circ}C\) room, its temperature is \(11^{\circ}C\).

Assuming that the temperature of the apple satisfies Newton’s Law of Cooling, write the differential equation satisfied by the temperature \(T(t)\) of the apple at time t.
statement_latex:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show
all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there.
Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

When an apple is taken from a refrigerator, its temperature is
$3^{\circ}C$. After 30 minutes in a $19^{\circ}C$ room, its temperature
is $11^{\circ}C$.

Assuming that the temperature of the apple satisfies Newton's Law of
Cooling, write the differential equation satisfied by the temperature
$T(t)$ of the apple at time \emph{t}.
statement_raw:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

When an apple is taken from a refrigerator, its temperature is <math> 3^{\circ}C </math>. After 30 minutes in a <math> 19^{\circ}C </math> room, its temperature is <math> 11^{\circ}C</math>.

Assuming that the temperature of the apple satisfies Newton's Law of Cooling, write the differential equation satisfied by the temperature <math> T(t) </math> of the apple at time ''t''.
